facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated 10, 1958 of Circuit Bench of Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writs Nos. 301, 302 and 347 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated 10, 1958, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab, High Court at Delhi in Civil Writs Nos. 301, 302. a d. 347 of 1956.

facts.text: Three petitions under Article 226 of the Constitution filed by three companies manufacturing vegetable products known as Vanaspati.

anchor.surface_text: all three petitions under Art 226 of the. Constitution. The three petitions are by three different companypanies manufacturing vegetable products known as Vanaspati

facts.text: Petitions challenge legality of imposition of excise duty on manufacture of refined oil from raw oil.

anchor.surface_text: and they challenge the legality of the imposition of Excise duty on, what was called by the taxing authorities as the manufacture of refined from raw oil.

facts.text: Petitioners purchased groundnut and til oil from open market or directly from manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioners purchased groundnut and  the respondents herein  til oil from the open market or directly from the manufacturers of such oil.

facts.text: Oils purchased are subjected to different processes to turn them into Vanaspati.

anchor.surface_text: The oils thus purchased are subjected to different processes in order to turn them into Vanaspati.

facts.text: Only finished product manufactured is Vanaspati, liable to excise duty as vegetable product.

anchor.surface_text: It is their case that the only finished product they manufacture from the raw materials thus purchased is Vanaspati which is liable to exciseduty as a vegetable product.

anchor.surface_text: They, companytend that at numberstage do they produce any new product which can companye within the item described in the Schedule as vegetable number-essential, oils all sorts

facts.text: Refined oil falls within vegetable non-essential oils liable to excise duty under item 23.

anchor.surface_text: at one stage, after carrying out some process with the aid of power, what is known to market as refined oil. This refined oil falls within the description of vegetable number-essential oils

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Mr. P. S. Krishnan, Chief Chemist, describing refining process.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit filed. by Mr. P. S Krishnan, Chief Chemist, Central Revenue, Central Laboratory,Government of India, in support of this companytention of the appellant

facts.text: Manufacture of Vanaspati consists in hydrogenating oils using catalyst on refined vegetable non-essential oil free from impurities.

anchor.surface_text: The manufacture of vegetable product companysists in hydrogenating oils using a catalyst. ... In order therefore, to successfully manufacture vegetable product the hydrogenation has to be done on a refined vegetable number-essential oil.

facts.text: Refining process: adding alkali solution to form soap, settling, drawing supernatant, treating with bleaching earth and carbon, filtering.

anchor.surface_text: The process of refining them companysists in adding. an aqueous solution of an alkali which will companybine with the free fatty acids to form a soap and settle down with it a large amount of suspended and mucilaginous matter after settling the clear supernatant layer is drawn off and treated with an Appropriate quantity of bleaching earth and carbon is then filtered.

facts.text: After refining, oil is suitable for hydrogenation into Vanaspati and process involves power and machinery.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage the oil is a refined oil and is suitable for hydrogenation into vegetable product. This process of refining generally involves the use of power and machinery.

facts.text: Refined oil suitable for edible purposes, toilet goods; sometimes further deodorised.

anchor.surface_text: Depending upon the quality of the seed used for crushing and that of the original raw oil this refined oil will number generally be suitable for edible purposes of discriminating users and for the manufacture of toilet goods like hair oils and high class soaps.

facts.text: Refined oils marketed separately as refined groundnut oil.

anchor.surface_text: As far as known to me, the two grades of oils are separately marketed in the companyntry as for example, groundnut oil and refined groundnut oil the latter generally with a distinctive label

facts.text: Experts for petitioners agree impurities removed before hydrogenation but refined oil requires deodorisation.

Dr. Nanji is definite... refined oil for edible purposes... is oil to which all the three processes, viz., neutralization, bleaching and deodorisation

facts.text: High Court accepted petitioners' contention and allowed petitions, directing withdrawal of excise demand.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated the High Court accepted the petitioners companytention that the oil in their hands after some amount of refinement in the companyrse of being companyverted into Vanaspati was number liable to excise duty under item 23  Now item 12  and so allowed the petitions.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 12, 1962 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. October 12. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-These , three appeals are against the orders of the Punjab, High Court

facts.text: Indian Standards Institution specifies refined groundnut oil as neutralised, bleached and deodorised.

holdings.text: The raw oil purchased by the respondents for the purpose of manufacture of Vanaspati does not become at any stage refined oil as is known to the consumers and the commercial community.

On a consideration of all these materials we have no doubt about the correctness of the respondents case that the raw oil purchased by the respondents for the purpose of manufacture of Vanaspati does not become at any stage refined oil

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from experts, Indian Standards Institution specifications requiring deodorisation, and affidavits of marketing concerns showing no marketing of refined oil without deodorisation; no counter-evidence from appellants.

holdings.text: There is no liability to excise duty under item 23 of the First Schedule to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 on the intermediate product produced by the petitioners.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No production of refined oil known to market at any stage; processes do not amount to manufacture of excisable goods under item 23.

holdings.text: The processes of neutralisation by alkali and bleaching by activated earth or carbon applied to raw oil do not amount to manufacture of a new substance known to the market liable to duty under item 23.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Equating processing to manufacture has no warrant; requires bringing new substance known to market.

holdings.text: Manufacture means bringing into existence a new substance known to the market and does not mean merely to produce some change in a substance.

anchor.surface_text: The word manufacture used as a verb is generally understood to mean as bringing into existence a new substance and does not mean merely to produce some change in a substance, however minor in consequence the change may be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning supported by quoted authorities requiring transformation to new article with distinctive name, character or use; goods must be marketable commodity.

holdings.text: The definition of 'manufacture' in section 2(f) does not equate any processing or change to manufacture liable to excise duty but clarifies inclusion of incidental or ancillary processes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose is to cover processes with aid of power in relation to manufacture of finished article known to market, not to make mere processing liable.

holdings.text: Excise duty is on the manufacture of goods and not on the sale; liability not affected if intermediate product used captively.

anchor.surface_text: Excise duty is on the manufacture of goods and not on the sale. Mr. Pathak is therefore right in his contention that the fact that the substance produced by them

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges counsel's contention as correct, but no manufacture here so immaterial.

holdings.text: 'All sorts' in item 23 covers vegetable non-essential oils raw or refined from whatever source, but requires manufacture of substance known to the market.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak wanted to derive some assistance, for his argument from the words all sorts as used in the clause. According to him, the words all sorts will be superfluous

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words make clear coverage of various kinds but duty on manufacture of known goods.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in, its conclusion that there was numberlegal basis for the demands of excise duty which were made. on the petitioners and in directing the authorities to withdraw these demands.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order upheld; no legal basis for excise duty demands on intermediate product; authorities directed to withdraw demands
directions: excise authorities to withdraw the impugned demands of excise duty
